question: R.H. Whittaker (1969) proposed a ______ Kingdom Classification.
The kingdoms defined by him were named Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae and ______.
The main criteria for classification included cell structure, body organisation, mode of nutrition, reproduction and ______ relationships.
Table 2.1 gives a comparative account of different characteristics of the ______ kingdoms.
The ______-domain system has also been proposed.
The three-domain system divides the Kingdom Monera into ______ domains.
The three-domain system results in a ______ kingdom classification.
You will learn about this system in ______ classes.
Let us look at this ______ kingdom classification to understand the issues.
Earlier classification systems included bacteria, blue green algae, fungi, mosses, ferns, gymnosperms and the ______ under ‘Plants’.
All the organisms included had a cell ______ in their cells.
It brought together the prokaryotic bacteria and the blue green algae, also called ______.
It brought together prokaryotic and ______ groups.
It also grouped together the ______ organisms and the multicellular ones.
Chlamydomonas and ______ were placed together under algae.
The classification did not differentiate between the ______ group – fungi, and the autotrophic green plants.
The fungi had ______ in their walls.
The green plants had a ______ cell wall.
The fungi were placed in a separate kingdom – Kingdom ______.
All ______ organisms were grouped together under Kingdom Monera.
The unicellular eukaryotic organisms were placed in Kingdom ______.

Paramoecium and ______ were earlier placed in the animal kingdom.
Paramoecium and Amoeba lack ______ wall.
The criteria for classification ______, resulting in new kingdoms.
Classification changes with improvement in our understanding of characteristics and ______ relationships.
Over time, a classification system was evolved which reflects not only similarities but is also ______.
The evolved system is based on evolutionary ______.
Fungi had ______ in their cell wall.
Green plants had a ______ cell wall.
Monera includes all ______ organisms.
Protista includes unicellular ______ organisms.
Fungi and green plants showed difference in wall ______.
The fungi were placed in a ______ kingdom.
Amoeba and Paramoecium were placed in ______ Kingdom in earlier classifications.
This kind of changes will take place in ______ too.
Classification also reflects ______ similarities.
Classification also reflects ______ similarities.
Classification also reflects ______ similarities.
Fungi were placed in a separate kingdom when their ______ were considered.
Earlier classification placed Chlamydomonas and Chlorella in ______.
The five kingdom classification helped address issues in earlier ______.
Cyanobacteria is another name for blue green ______.
Fungi and green plants differ in their wall ______.
Cell wall presence was the unifying character under kingdom ______.
A system was evolved based on ______ relationships.
Gymnosperms and angiosperms were both grouped under ______.
This classification system brought together groups which differed in other ______.
Whittaker's classification includes ______ kingdoms.
Blue green algae were grouped with ______ groups.
Amoeba and Paramoecium were placed in Kingdom ______.
All organisms in Plants had a ______ wall.
The third domain includes the remaining ______ kingdoms.
Fungi are ______ while green plants are autotrophic.
Bacteria are the sole members of the Kingdom ______.
They are the most abundant ______.
Bacteria occur almost ______.
Hundreds of bacteria are present in a handful of ______.
They live in extreme habitats such as hot springs, deserts, snow and deep ______.
Very few other life forms can ______ there.
Many of them live in or on other organisms as ______.
Bacteria are grouped under ______ categories based on shape.
The spherical bacteria are called ______ (pl.: cocci).
The rod-shaped bacteria are called ______ (pl.: bacilli).
The comma-shaped bacteria are called ______ (pl.: vibrio).
The spiral-shaped bacteria are called ______ (pl.: spirilla).
Though the bacterial structure is simple, they are complex in ______.
Bacteria show the most extensive ______ diversity.
Some of the bacteria are ______, i.e., they synthesise their own food.
Autotrophic bacteria synthesise food from ______ substrates.
Autotrophic bacteria may be photosynthetic or ______.
The vast majority of bacteria are ______.
